results.title: Rembrandt. Part III: beyond art
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rembrandt”.
Sir Kenneth Clark, eminent British art authority introduces the series of three films on the life and work of the Dutch painter, Rembrandt. In this last part, it shows how Rembrandt retained the moment of vision in all his paintings, and illustrates his marvellous ability for detail as exemplified in the fleyed ox. His many portraits show his intense self-insight and his humorous acceptance of life. His wonderful sense of balance and space is illustrated especially in “The Old Woman” and a group of “Important Men in Amsterdam”.

results.title: Rembrandt. Part II: life and art
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rembrandt”.
Sir Kenneth Clark introduces a series of three films on the life and work of the Dutch painter, Rembrandt. At the height of his success in 1642 Rembrandt amassed a large fortune, which he fritted away before his wife’s death. There were difficult years ahead. Discusses Rembrandt’s greater master of character; his increased, more “dramatic” interest in landscape. By 1664 his use of the classic rather than the baroque design marked a turning point in his career.

results.title: Rembrandt. Part I: success story
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rembrandt”.
Sir Kenneth Clark, eminent British art authority introduces the series of three films on the life and work of the Dutch painter, Rembrandt. Rembrandt’s early life and work are described in this first film. He was born in Leyden in 1606; his family recognised his talent and sent him to Amsterdam to study. His brilliant drawing and skilful use of oils established his reputation. In 1631 he settled in Amsterdam and married Saskia van Uylenborch three years later. He painted his wife many times and the period of his early married life contains many happy and light-hearted pictures.

results.title: Rembrandt's - The Three Crosses
results.creator_credit: Dudley Shaw Ashton, Arts Council of Great Britain and Balfour Films
results.brief_description: A detailed account of the engraving of the original plate for Rembrandt’s celebrated print; the artist’s experimental use of different papers and methods of inking, and the later re-working of the plate. Commentary written and spoken by Christopher White.

results.title: Remain
results.brief_description: In her 2018 2-channel video work Remain, Iranian born Melbourne artist Hoda Afshar works with several of the refugees who remain on Manus Island, encouraging the men to ‘re-enact their narratives with their own bodies and [gives] them autonomy to narrate their own stories’.

constellations_other.name: Seeking asylum
constellations_other.description: Chauka Please Tell Us the Time was covertly filmed on a smartphone inside the Manus Island Detention Centre and sent via WhatsApp.

results.description: In her 2018 2-channel video work Remain, Iranian born Melbourne artist Hoda Afshar works with several of the refugees who remain on Manus Island, encouraging the men to ‘re-enact their narratives with their own bodies and [gives] them autonomy to narrate their own stories’.

results.title: Reluctant warriors - 1939
results.brief_description: A summary of events in Britain in 1939 at the beginning of World War II, including the dramatic radio announcement of the declaration of war, evacuation of children from the cities, landing of the British Expeditionary Force in France and the actual beginning of the War at sea. Narrated by Sir Michael Redgrave. Written by Peter Baylis.

results.title: Religion and magic
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Coast Community College District and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “Faces of culture”.
Man’s quest for meaning, coupled with the idea of an ultimate reality beyond daily existence is evident in all societies. Religion explains the unknown, provides a common purpose and values for a community, helps weave all elements of society into one design and provides world views and belief systems that give meaning to all that humanity is and does. Religions can express harmony and balance, as with the North American Indians and Balinese Hinduism. Religions can be modified as cultures interact, can descend into magic and shamanism, or, as in industrialised society be relegated to special occasions or banned altogether. Although science seems to provide answers it is said that “the cosmos looks more and more like a great thought”. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Relatives (AFC)
results.creator_credit: Antony J. Bowman, Basil Appleby, Henri Safran, Archer Films and Quantum Films
results.brief_description: Set in beautiful cattle farming country New South Wales during the 1980s, this quirky comedy drama centres around a family reunion to celebrate grandfather’s 80th birthday. Spanning three generations, the relatives all gather at the historical family homestead, some from the city and others from the country. Add to this an intruder from Czechoslovakia, lots of alcohol, family jealousies and rivalries, “dangerous” liaisons, a somewhat bewildered and bemused grandfather, and an important announcement which will affect the whole family, there can be only one outcome - disaster. Cast includes Bill Kerr, Rowena Wallace, Carol Raye, Ray Barrett and Norman Kaye. Music written and played by Norman Kaye and photography by Tom Cowan.

results.title: Relative strangers
results.brief_description: Family ties are often a fragile thing, as Simon is about to discover as he unravels the secrets of one man’s childhood. A haunting look at the issues facing modern family life.
